results.title: The Case of Barbara Parsons
results.creator_credit: Rob Iveson, Parker Film Associates, Labor Canada and Morten Parker
results.brief_description: Barbara Parsons, a recent employee, is promoted to a position ahead of Michael Blais a company employee of 19 years. Dramatizes a situation that could occur in any unionized workplace - the violation of a contract between management and labour and illustrates the four main steps of the grievance procedure.

results.title: The Case against rubella
results.brief_description: Shows rubella-damaged children with various handicaps, including blindness and brain damage. Outlines the history of the disease and stresses that Rubella and its serious consequences can now be prevented by newly developed vaccines. Briefly shows research efforts and how the vaccines are to be used

results.title: The Cars that ate Paris. The Plumber [DVD]
results.brief_description: The Plumber: There is an unexpected knock on the door and Jilly (Judy Morris) an anthropologist, opens it to a strange man who says he is the plumber (Ivor Kants). Weir deftly crafts a tense thriller, as the man is not all he seems and Jilly is tormented by the man’s presence and mind games over the next five days as he totally disrupts her life. Her husband, a university doctor (Robert Coleby), seems oblivious to her anguish and just wants the shower fixed. Disturbing and unsettling in mood, set in a high-rise apartment block with large balconies that feel lifeless and unconducive to a happy life, Jilly plots to play the plumber at his own game and foils his plans. Written and directed by Peter Weir. Production company: SAFC/Channel 9/AFC, copyright by Salt Pan Films 1978/2004, produced by Matt Carroll. Also available on VHS [301733]. The Cars that ate Paris: Peter Weir’s directorial feature film debut is an offbeat horror story/fantasy about a small Australian country town called Paris. Giving the term ‘road kill’ a whole new meaning, the townsfolk of Paris make a living out of the victims of road accidents by allowing a crazy psychiatrist to conduct experiments on them. They also prosper from the cars that cause the accidents but death, destruction and mayhem ensue as the cars turn against the town. John Meillon is wonderful as the chipper Town Mayor and Terry Camilleri portrays the disbelief in his character’s predicament very well. Production Company was AFDC and Royce Smeal Film Productions with copyright by Salt Pan Films 1974/2001. Produced by Hal and Jim McElroy and written and directed by Peter Weir. Cast includes: Chris Haywood, Bruce Spence, Kevin Miles, Max Gillies, Melissa Jaffer, Max Phipps. Released on DVD by ScreenSound Australia. Also available on VHS [016312].

results.title: The Cars That Ate China
results.creator_credit: Jumping Dog Productions, Ard Norddeutscher Rundfunk, Stefan Moore, Susan Lambert and Frank Haines
results.brief_description:
China is in the midst of an automotive revolution that has not been witnessed since the halcyon days of Henry Ford. Cars are now the ultimate symbol of status and prosperity in a country that is well on its way to becoming the biggest economy in the world.
But car culture is also bringing about volatile class divisions, the world’s worst air pollution, and fierce global competition for limited resources. And it’s only just begun.
Today, car culture is everywhere - in television ads, glossy magazines, glitzy showrooms and international auto shows with scantily clad models. For China’s rising middle class, the new prosperity symbolised by the car is intoxicating. For the future of Chinese society, the environment and the world, some of the prospects are chilling.
The film is set in Beijing, once called the ‘Bicycle Kingdom’ and now the epicentre of China’s exploding car culture. The story is a poignant and surprising parable about a world that has profound repercussions for our own.

results.title: The Cars in your life
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Tom Daly, Wolf Koenig, Roman Kroitor and Terence Macartney-Filgate
results.brief_description: A light, humorous look at the motor car and the great North American itch for a place on the road. From the comparative peace of Honest Joe’s used-car lot, this film hurries you onto our public speedways, where hot rubber erases any distance between all points. Slow-motion and pop-on-pop photography make this a provocative, revealing study of motormania unlimited.

results.title: The Carpetbaggers
results.creator_credit: Joseph E. Levine, Paramount Pictures and Edward Dmytryk
results.brief_description: The explosive and frank adaptation of the best-selling Harold Robbins novel stars George Peppard as the ruthless tycoon who, with amazing parallels to Howard Hughes, manages to build a multi-million dollar empire. Set in the 20s and 30s, it provides an insight into life in Hollywood, filled with “booze and broads”. The plot centres on the eternal themes of greed, corruption, power, passion and love. The noteworthy cast also includes Elizabeth Ashley, Lew Ayres, Martin Balsam, Archie Moore, Martha Hyer, Leif Erickson, and Alan Ladd in his last performance. Costumes are by Dame Edith Head and music by Elmer Bernstein.

results.title: The Carp = Saran
results.creator_credit: Zagreb Film, Alexsandar Marks and Vladimir Jutrisa
results.brief_description: Animator Aleksandar Marks is a master of several graphical styles. Philosophically, he feels at home in the world of Kafka, Camus, the Bauhaus, Kathe Kollwitz and German expressionism. His favourite topic is the increasing loneliness of human beings in the industrial society. This particular animated film tells the story of a small boy and an older man fishing together by a river. Later the boy catches a huge carp in a sweet shop where the fish proceeds to produce lots of sweets for the boy. Finally the boy floats away pulled along by a balloon. Animated by Alexsandar Marks and Vladimir Jutrisa.

results.title: The Carp
results.creator_credit: Maxwell Munden and Max Munden Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Anglers’ Corner”.
One of a series of films on inland water fishing in England, introduced by Bernard Venables. Shows Leslie Brewer bottom fishing for carp in a Dorset lake early one summer morning. Gives facts about the fish, where it feeds and where to find it, tackle and bait used, and how to play the catch.

results.title: The Carnot cycle and the Kelvin temperature scale
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “College Physics”.
The motion of a piston in a cylinder and a moving point on a pressure-volume diagram are used in explaining the four ideal processes which constitute the Carnot cycle. Shows heat being absorbed and rejected during the cycle and defines the Kelvin scale.

results.title: The Caribou hunters
results.creator_credit: Tom Daly, ONF | NFB and Stephen Greenless
results.brief_description: The Cree and Chippewa Indians of northern Manitoba lead a nomadic life as they roam the northern stretches of forest and tundra in search of the caribou that is their main source of food. The camera follows a group of Indian hunters with their dog teams as they move with the herds and at the same time trap the smaller animals of the forest and streams. Their focal point is the Hudson’s Bay Company trading post, where they bring their furs to exchange for the few essentials of their hardy existence. We also see their camp life, and examples of their colorful handicrafts. (Award: Dusseldorf)
